title: 106_s2946
content:
The Employee Benefits Eligibility Fairness Act of 2000 may be cited as the "Employee Benefits Eligibility Fairness Act." The Employee Benefits Eligibility Fairness Act of 2000 aims to protect workers' pension and welfare benefits by addressing the mislabeling of employees to exclude them from benefit plans. Mislabeled employees, such as temporary or part-time workers, are denied benefits that should be available to them. (2) Mislabeled employees are often paid through staffing or temporary firms to appear as if they do not work for their actual employer. This violates the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. (3) Employers are adjusting benefit plans to include mislabeled employees. Employers are amending benefit plans to exclude mislabeled employees from participating, even if they are eligible. Mislabeled employees are often required to sign documents waiving their rights to participate in benefit plans, which violates the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 clarifies provisions to prevent employees from being wrongly excluded from benefit plans due to mislabeling of their employment status. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL STANDARDS RELATING TO MINIMUM PARTICIPATION REQUIREMENTS. The text chunk discusses an amendment to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 regarding the inclusion of service for the employer as an employee under common law, regardless of the payment arrangement. This includes service through staffing firms, direct payment by the employer, or payment from a non-payroll account. The amendment to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 states that a pension plan must include all employees who perform the same work as others not excluded from the plan, regardless of their employment category. The amendment to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ensures that all employees performing the same work must be included in a pension plan, except for those who do not meet the plan's minimum service period or age requirements. The amendment to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 prohibits waivers of participation in pension or welfare plans based on employee miscategorization. Additionally, objective eligibility criteria must be included in plan instruments. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 now requires that employee benefit plans must have written eligibility criteria based on job classifications and objective criteria, prohibiting exclusion of employees based on common law regardless of their worker category. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 mandates that employee benefit plans must have written eligibility criteria based on job classifications and objective criteria, preventing exclusion of employees based on common law, regardless of their worker category. Employees must meet specific criteria to participate in the plan, including being classified as an employee under common law, performing similar work as other employees not excluded from the plan, and meeting minimum service period or age requirements. SEC. 6. ENFORCEMENT.

Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act to provide relief to employees who have been miscategorized in violation of certain sections.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The amendments apply to plan years starting after the enactment of the Act.
